skills.name: Add proper fractions with the same denominator
Add proper fractions with different denominators where one is a multiple of the other
Subtract proper fractions with the same denominator
Subtract proper fractions with different denominators where one is a multiple of the other

explanations.A: When the denominators are the same we can just add the numerators. 2/5 + 1/5 = 3/5
explanations.B: When we add fractions like this we only add the numerators. We don't add the denominators.
explanations.C: I think you might have subtracted the fractions rather than adding them.
explanations.D: I think you might have multiplied the fractions rather than adding them.

explanations.A: I think you might have multiplied the numerators rather than adding them.
explanations.B: When the denominators are the same we can just add the numerators. 3/8 + 2/8 = 5/8
explanations.C: When we add fractions like this we only add the numerators. We don't add the denominators.
explanations.D: I think you might have subtracted the fractions rather than adding them.

explanations.A: To add, these fractions need the same denominator. 1/3 = 3/9 and then 2/9 + 3/9 = 5/9.
explanations.B: I think you have added the numerators and denominators together. Convert 1/3 to have a denominator of 9, and then add only the numerators.
explanations.C: We can't add these fractions until their denominators are the same. Convert 1/3 to have a denominator of 9.
explanations.D: I think you have subtracted the numerators and denominators. Convert 1/3 to have a denominator of 9, and then add the numerators.

explanations.A: I think you have added the numerators and denominators together. Convert 3/5 to have a denominator of 15, and then only add the numerators.
explanations.B: We can't add these fractions until their denominators are the same. Convert 3/5 to have a denominator of 15.
explanations.C: To add, these fractions need the same denominator. 3/5 = 9/15 and then 9/15 + 2/15 = 11/15.
explanations.D: Not quite. Convert 3/5 to have a denominator of 15, and then add the numerators.

explanations.A: I think you might have added the second fraction instead of subtracting it.
explanations.B: When the denominators are the same we can just subtract the numerators. 3/8 − 2/8 = 1/8.
explanations.C: I think you have added the numerators and denominators. When fractions have the same denominator we add or subtract only their numerators.
explanations.D: I think you have subtracted the numerators and denominators. When fractions have the same denominator we add or subtract only their numerators.

explanations.A: When the denominators are the same we can just subtract the numerators. 6/7 − 2/7 = 4/7.
explanations.B: Not quite, check you working carefully. What is 6 − 2?
explanations.C: You have subtracted the numerators but added the denominators. When fractions have the same denominator we add or subtract only their numerators.
explanations.D: I think you have subtracted the numerators and denominators. When fractions have the same denominator we add or subtract only their numerators.

explanations.A: I think you have subtracted the numerators and denominators. First convert 1/3 to have a denominator of 9, and then subtract only the numerators.
explanations.B: We can't subtract these fractions until their denominators are the same. First convert 1/3 to have a denominator of 9.
explanations.C: You have added the second fraction instead of subtracting it.
explanations.D: To subtract, these fractions need the same denominator. 1/3 = 3/9 and then 5/9 − 3/9 = 2/9.

explanations.A: This calculation is possible. First convert 3/5 to have a denominator of 15, and then subtract only the numerators.
explanations.B: We can't subtract these fractions until their denominators are the same. First convert 3/5 to have a denominator of 15.
explanations.C: To subtract, these fractions need the same denominator. 3/5 = 9/15 and then 9/15 − 3/15 = 6/15.
explanations.D: I think you have added the numerators and denominators. First convert 3/5 to have a denominator of 15, and then subtract only the numerators.

explanations.A: I think you have subtracted the numerators and denominators.First simplify 6/9 to have a denominator of 3.
explanations.B: We can't subtract these fractions until their denominators are the same. First simplify 6/9 to have a denominator of 3.
explanations.C: To subtract, these fractions need the same denominator. 6/9 simplifies to 2/3 and then 2/3 − 2/3 = 0.
explanations.D: Not quite. To subtract, these fractions need the same denominator. First simplify 6/9 to have a denominator of 3.

explanations.A: This calculation is possible. First convert 1/2 to have a denominator of 12, and then subtract only the numerators.
explanations.B: To subtract, these fractions need the same denominator. 1/2 = 6/12 and then 6/12 − 1/12 = 5/12.
explanations.C: I think you have subtracted the denominators and left the numerator as 1. To subtract these fractions, first convert 1/2 to have a denominator of 12, and then subtract only the numerators.
explanations.D: You have added the second fraction instead of subtracting it.
